TopicTitle: The Venturer Program: Tour of the planets

Articles.Content:
Hats off to the Rosetta Rendezvous guys!

Woo!

Man, the story gets better and better every time I check back and read it! Out of curiosity, where are the Jool and skybox textures?

Thanks

The Skybox (well, the most recent one...) I pulled from Space Engine; it's from inside the Large Magellanic Cloud, a place that I think seems quite nice for the Kerbals to reside. The Jool texture is from Better Atmospheres.

Oh, and sorry it's taking a while for the next chapter, I sort of let them catch up on me again

CHAPTER 38: THE DANCE WITH THE GIANT

A few days later...

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You know, I did always admire Jool. Even from Kerbin, it was unmistakably unique, and then there were all those mothership attempts that failed over and over again for one reason or another, like Jool was just daring us to get near it. Had I been in the space industry when Odysseus was planned, I'd have signed up for it in an instant.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know what you mean. I'd never been beyond Minmus when I signed up for that mission. The very fact that I got selected was astonishing. I did have a gut feeling that something bad might happen when thinking back to the Triton and Everest attempts, but clearly we learnt from mistakes and finally achieved what we'd been hoping to achieve.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And look at us now, just an hour from dipping into its clouds again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Maybe we'll get some insight into why its changed its appearance so quickly.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's what I'm hoping for. My hypothesis is still just that; I need to know what's going on inside Jool and we're only going to be getting that sort of info from this aerobrake. Of course, this is all assuming the ship doesn't break up...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, I've been keeping a good eye on the ship, so let me tell you right now that we won't blow up.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, ok. I was only saying that because the ship is showing some wear and tear after having been out here for so long with minimal support from home.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is, and that's why I'm working almost around the clock to keep it from being more than just wear and tear. Don't worry, exploding is for another day.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's reassuring.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm. Anyway, I suppose I'd best be keeping an eye on Jool, see if I can spot any reason as to why it looks like this.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right.Ã¢â‚¬Â

One hour later...

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Solar panels are clear.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good. We don't want to lose them all the way out here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nope.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, here we go again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Entering atmosphere now. Alert; I've detected strong winds close to our periapsis. We may need to alter course upon leaving the atmosphere.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“How strong are we talking, Stanley?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm estimating about 372kmh wind speeds to the east, but we may also experience turbulence in other directions.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then. Everyone, really make sure your seatbelts are fastened, this could get bumpy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And I just had carrots for lunch...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh Kod.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alert, temperatures may reach levels higher than anticipated. I'm also detecting slight buffeting from the winds.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“How much higher will those temperatures get?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hard to say, I'm afraid, Jeb. Just remain alert.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's hardly useful, Stanley!Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I apologise.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn, the landers are lighting up like fireworks!Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Both landers are beginning to exceed their temperature tolerances. Detecting damage to multiple systems. Warning, g-forces greater than anticipated.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Frak! Bill, how much longer?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're beginning to... climb again!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I can hear sparks!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh Kod, I don't wanna... die!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it, just... hold together a little... longer!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Hull integrity has dropped... to 71%, Jeb!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Agh, almost there!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jim's passed out!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mac and Ed have black out, too!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Crap!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Both medical officers?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Instating emergency conditions. Warning, multiple structural failures in both landers.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're almost out!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Deceleration is negligible, someone go and wake the doctors up!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm on it!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're clear! Thank Kod!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sheesh, I don't remember Jool being this vicious the last time we were here...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it, I've got to check these landers!Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No hull breaches detected. Pressure is remaining stable. Enterprise itself is intact, but the landers are going to need significant repair work.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it, I'm going to need help back here!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'll come and give you a hand in a moment!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good Kod, the ship hasn't been this abuzz with activity for ages!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it, where's Mac?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Out cold!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ed?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Same!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Frak! Jim hit his head when he blacked out, I need help here!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it! Stanley, give me a rundown of the crew's condition.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mac, Ed, Franklin, Jim, and Matt have all been rendered unconscious. All but Jim are uninjured.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So Jim's our priority right now. Someone wake the docs up!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm on it! Where are the ammonia sticks?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“They should be in the first aid kit closest to the centrifuge tunnel!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Let's see... got 'emÃ¢â‚¬Â Hold your breath, Buzz!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh good Kod, this stinks!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: *cough cough* Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh Kod, why do I smell ammonia??Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ed, how many fingers am I holding up?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bleh... uh, 2?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You're all good. Now for Mac.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I already sorted him out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mac: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And I never want to experience that again. My head...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Take an aspirin and go help Jim, he hit his head.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mac: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ugh, right...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Dean, let's get Matt and Franklin awake.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good idea.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Several minutes later...

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“My Kod...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What is it, are you alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm fine, it's just... look.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, we're in emergency conditions and you're looking out... the... window.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh wow...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's things like that that make everything we've been through worth it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Except for Sid.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Except for Sid. Everything else though...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm. Well, I suppose we do need someone up here to keep an eye on things lest something develops, so just be aware of--Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Tylo flyby? I know, I saw it on the display.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright then. I'll be back here helping out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Several hours later...

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, Commander Bill has authorised me to select Laythe as our target and prepare for any manoeuvre we must complete.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is that so? Alright then, Stanley, begin preparations to plot our course to Laythe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, Jeb. The first burn will be to raise our periapsis to Laythe's altitude.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I figured that much out on my own, Stanley.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We'll also be adjusting our inclination to bring us into the planes of Laythe, Vall, and Tylo.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yep, figured that one out too.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm sorry.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, don't be, you're just doing your job.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed I am.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Several more hours later...

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And that looks as flat as a pancake. Stanley, if you would please create the next manoeuvre node when ready.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Meanwhile...

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, Jim?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ugh... what... ow... wait, ow? Why does my head hurt?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mac: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Listen, you banged your head pretty hard during the aerobrake, so don't try to move.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Feels like a concussion... geez, that must have been one rough aerobrake. How long have I been out for?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“7 hours and 20 minutes.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn, we must have passed the apoapsis by now, I imagine?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, we're heading back to Laythe's altitude now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well good. At least we didn't explode.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yep.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mac: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jim, I do need to check that it's actually concussion and not something worse, so could you come up to the centrifuge with me?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I feel like if I move, I'm gonna puke.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mac: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, that does sound like concussion... ok, stay put and I'll bring some stuff down.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Like I'd be moving around like this, anyway.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal turns to Matt and Franklin.

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What about you two, are you ok?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I've been better, I must say.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm confused; my flight training put me through acceleration more vigorous than that and I still blacked out. That shouldn't have happened.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, you were stuck on Duna for years. That probably didn't help with your condition.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know, but still...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“As long as you're both fine.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, thanks Cal.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not a problem.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Some time later...

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, now that I'm sorted out back there, I suppose I can help out here again. Stanley, thanks for covering for me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You're welcome, Bill. I've already plotted the trajectory to give us a Laythe encounter.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, so you have. Looks a little tenuous, but ok, as long as it works. Jeb?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Zzz...zzz...zzz...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“AGH! WHAT, WHAT IS-- Oh, Bill. Sorry, I was tired...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, you're the captain, I can't tell you what to do, really, but we've got to do a burn, right now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah yes, ok. Is everyone strapped in?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, they're all good.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, let's do this.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Laythe encounter confirmed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I don't know, it still looks tenuous...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“But it's there, right?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is, but I have this bad feeling we won't actually be getting that far.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We'll see about that, won't we? What's the worst that could happen?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, you're right, what is the worst that could happen?Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few hours later...

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“FRAKKING TYLO!Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I don't understand; this did not show up at all on the trajectory plan.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's not you, Stanley, it's Tylo! Damn it!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We don't have the fuel to keep beating around the bush trying to get to Laythe! Decison time, Tylo now, or Laythe now?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, we're here now, so I say Tylo.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What, we hit Tylo?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, but it caught us while we were going to Laythe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, Tylo, what a b*stard.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bob, Laythe or Tylo first?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Tylo, seeing as we're flying past it right now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, Tylo it is. Bob, go and tell the crew of our slight change in plans.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, Jeb? I've just thought of a problem...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And that is?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jim's supposed to land here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I thought that was Lengas?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, the mission planners change it before we left. Jim's landing on Tylo.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“...Not with that head, he's not.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Exactly.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I'll just get Lengas to fly down there, then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lengas hasn't been practising the Tylo landing, though, not since we left Kerbin.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Aw crap.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Tylo is the new Ike?

Hoo boy.

Tylo is the new Ike?

Hoo boy.

Tylo is Tylo; it will always find a way to snag you while you're busy doing something else around Jool...

CHAPTER 39: TYLO Ã¢â‚¬â€œ PART 1

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right, let's see...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There we go, let's get this thing moving.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Err, who are you talking to, Cal?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Myself, I guess. I'm just bringing the fuel tanker into a rendezvous with us.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah yes, your logistics side, I forgot about that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Which I'm not bothered about in the slightest. I am mainly an astrophysicist, but I got landed with both jobs for the mission. I don't know why, mind you, but hey, what can I do?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eh... damn, I need another aspirin. That aerobrake was rough.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I thought Eve was bad, but this one snatched the cake right from the maw of that purple death trap.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Heh.Ã¢â‚¬Â

With that, Jeb and several others file into the hab.

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, what's happening?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We've got a situation.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I figured as much, what with you practically storming in here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, just come up to the table area, would you? I'm convening a meeting.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh. Ok then, but just let me finalise the tanker's trajectory.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jim, what are you doing here?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Captain wants me here for this, too... hngh... Could someone dim the lights a little?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Dimming lights to 75% of current brightness.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, thank you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is everyone here?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Where's Bob?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bob? Bob!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Huh, what?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Meeting, now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, ok, I'll be right there.Ã¢â‚¬Â *yawn*

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“This had better be important because those landers aren't gonna fix themselves, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hopefully this won't take long.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right, I'm here. What's the prob-- oh, wait, never mind.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Let's make a start then. I'm sure you're all aware of our very slight deviation from the mission plan owing to unforeseen circumstances. We were heading to Laythe and then Tylo grabbed us, so now we're sat about 400km above the latter's surface. While that may not seem quite so problematic, especially seeing as we can refuel sooner rather than later, there is one hitch; the Tylo landing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“...What about it, Jeb? This is my landing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know that, Jim, and that's precisely the problem. With your head the way it is, there's no way I'm letting you go down there. We need someone to fill the gap, and Lengas, I'd like that someone to be you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now hold on a second!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, what?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lengas, you've got the most experience with the landing technique after Jim, so you're most suited to replace him.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Captain!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, I can't! I haven't practised this thing since we left Kerbin and the mission plan changed! Add to that the fact that if I'm gone, the landers won't be getting fixed and we could be facing severe delays later in the mission, and substituting me for Jim is a horrible idea!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn, I knew you would say something like that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm not one of these advanced pilots like you or Jim, anyway! I can only just fly the landers, along with other basic ships! Seriously, I'm not good for the Tylo landing and I downright refuse to do it, even if that means insubordinating you!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good Kod, are you really that certain?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“If I weren't, I wouldn't be yelling at you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Forgive me, but why are the rest of us here, Captain?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“In case something like this happened. I need a pilot for this landing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Captain, my head isn't that bad!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mac?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mac: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I will admit it's not the worst concussion I've seen, but flying the Tylo landing is out of the question in his condition.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There Jim, doctors orders.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, I won't have this! I'm doing this landing, one way or another!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I won't allow it!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“One way or another, I said! Why don't we wait a week and see how I am then? Does that sound good?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's not a bad idea, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And what if you're not alright in a week?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Then make it two!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We can't wait around that long, Jim!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well I can!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok guys, let's chill out. Now, how about this; we give Jim his week, but we get someone, say... Dean? Yeah, Dean. We train him up for the Tylo landing in case Jim isn't fit enough. Best case scenario, Jim gets his landing. Worst case, Dean does Tylo and Jim gets whatever Dean was scheduled to fly next.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bob, there are times when you inspire me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think that settles that. Does anybody have any questions?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, I do, uh... Why the hell did you pick me, Bob?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What? I just thought of some pilots and it boiled down to you and Buzz! Obviously I wasn't going to put Buzz through another stressful mission, so you fit the bill!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What about Jeb, though?!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What about me??Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Why can't you train up for Tylo??Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We need him up here, and besides, I don't think he'd appreciate Jim getting the Laythe landing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well there's that...Ã¢â‚¬Â
